title: Elizabeth Hurley looks glamorous in a hot pink belted dress as she attends charity lunc
text:
Elizabeth Hurley made an appearance at the Future Dreams lunch at The Savoy Hotel on Monday after detailing her grandmother's secret breast cancer diagnosis.

The actress, 54, looked glamorous as she arrived at the event in a belted hot pink dress as she continues to raise awareness for the devastating disease.

Earlier in the day, Elizabeth appeared on This Morning and detailed losing her nan during a time 'when nobody spoke about it' back in 1992, and has since played a significant role in the fight against cancer for almost three decades.

Glam: Elizabeth Hurley made an appearance at the Future Dreams lunch at The Savoy Hotel on Monday after detailing her grandmother's secret breast cancer diagnosis

For the event, which was supported by Estee Lauder, Elizabeth wore her tumbling brunette tresses in loose glamorous curls, and opted for a full face of make-up complete with a dramatic smokey-eye look.

She added further pops of pink to her outfit with a pair of fuchsia suede stilettos and a metallic pink leather handbag, teamed with delicate hoop earrings.

The lunch included a two course meal and guests were treated to inspiring motivational speakers, a luxury auction and a performance from Jack Savoretti.

Future Dreams is a charity dedicated to raising funds for support, awareness and research for those touched by Breast Cancer.

Beauty: For the event, which was supported by Estee Lauder, Elizabeth wore her tumbling brunette tresses in loose glamorous curls, and opted for a full face of make-up complete with a dramatic smokey-eye look

During her This Morning appearance, Model Liz bravely told hosts Holly Willoughby and Phillip Schofield: 'I’ve been working to raise awareness for breast cancer for 25 years.

She added: 'I lost my grandmother to breast cancer. At that time, nobody spoke about breast cancer.'

The Austin Powers star previously revealed her relative showed her scars from a double mastectomy once she finally told her family about her diagnosis, but would often change the subject.

Reflecting on when breast cancer was a taboo subject, the Royals actress explained: 'When I started working for the breast cancer campaign, my grandmother had just died.

Brave: During her This Morning appearance, Model Liz bravely told hosts Holly Willoughby and Phillip Schofield: 'I’ve been working to raise awareness for breast cancer for 25 years

Beautiful: Jacquie Beltrao wore a strapless pink dress which was cinched around her waist with a glitzy belt

'When I was told it was started because women were dying, it really rang home for me, because she didn’t talk about it. There was no awareness, no pink ribbon campaign.'

During her work as a global ambassador for the Estee Lauder Companies' Breast Cancer Awareness Campaign, Liz has insisted she's witnessed 'great changes' in research and attitudes towards the disease.

The media personality urged: 'People aren’t checking their own breasts. If you’re too young to have a mammogram, which is under 50 or in some countries under 40, you have to check your breasts. We’re raising awareness but we’re raising funds too.

One in eight women will develop breast cancer at some point in their life. However, those who have already had the disease have double the risk of developing a new cancer in another area of the same breast, or in the other breast.

Dapper: Jack looked suave in a navy shirt teamed with a pair of black trousers

Fantastic floral: Melissa Hemsley wowed in a stunning satin green dress with floral detailing

Genetics are thought to be the reason - but in the majority of cases, the exact genes responsible have not yet been discovered.

Last week, the film star took to Instagram to share a poignant message about the disease.

She penned on her platform: 'Every 15 seconds, somewhere in the world, a woman is diagnosed with breast cancer. In one way or another, we’re all drawn together by this disease.

'Grab your favourite pink lipstick and help us fund life-saving research. Draw a pink ribbon on your hand, post a photo, and share why it’s #TimeToEndBreastCancer.'
